description:
So Greece has spoken loud and clear: no to austerity in the referendum; no to the terms its creditors were offering for further funding. But will it also effectively mean as some are now predicting: no to Greece's place in the Eurozone? Well, the news was a queue for a big party on the streets of Syntagma Square in the centre of Athens last night. The BBC's Sarah Stallots was there for us.

Sarah, no voter's pretty happy. What did they feel they were voting for in this referendum?

Yes. That's a very good question, Ed. Well, last night there were scenes of jubilation, defiance. Lots of people were saying, you know, they were voting with their hearts, not their minds. But perhaps surprisingly, people were very pro-European. Even though they were saying no to austerity, the people I spoke to very much wanted to be part of Europe, and they were actually, they actually felt that this no vote would strengthen their hand in terms of Alexis Tsipras getting a better deal for the country. But you know, I mean, basically some people I spoke to were also saying to be honest this has gone so far now. It's actually not about austerity anymore. It's not about getting a deal. It's just about getting a little bit of dignity back and that counts for a whole lot for the people I spoke to, especially after a long five years of hardship.
